instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no imagem on the internal display, but it has image on external display.

Already tried  known good  display and cable, but same result.

<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 5.1V

<SIGNAL>PANEL_P5V_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> = 0V, and 0.051 on diode reading

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL> = 0V and 0.830 on diode reading

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Did you check diode mode to ground on J8500?
Pay atention to pins 1 & 3.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I forgoted it...

Everything seams OK on J8500, except <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> that has 0.066 on diode to ground (not sure if it is a normal value cause it is a high voltage line).

Pins 1 and 3 have 0.261 diode to ground

I notice that when reading diode on <DIODE>D8410</DIODE>, when I reverse the multimeter tips, the current flows both ways. Already replaced the diode, and apparently it only happens when soldered to the board. I don't think it should, correct?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
0.066 is very low there; was this with LCD connected?
If not, probably bad filter cap on backlight output rail.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
It was a bad cap.

TKS!
